title: Brownville, Maine
text:
Brownville is a <a href="New%20England%20town">town</a> in <a href="Piscataquis%20County%2C%20Maine">Piscataquis County</a>, <a href="Maine">Maine</a>, United States. The population was 1,139 at the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20Census">2020 census</a>. The town includes the villages of Brownville, Knight's Landing and <a href="Brownville%20Junction%2C%20Maine">Brownville Junction</a>, near which passes the <a href="100-Mile%20Wilderness">100-Mile Wilderness</a> of the <a href="Appalachian%20Trail">Appalachian Trail</a>.
History.
The area was a part of the <a href="Waldo%20Patent">Waldo Patent</a> purchased by Moses Brown and Major Josiah Hill of <a href="Newburyport%2C%20Massachusetts">Newburyport</a>, <a href="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a>, who initiated its settlement. In 1806, they built a <a href="dam">dam</a> and <a href="watermill">watermill</a>s on the <a href="Pleasant%20River%20%28Piscataquis%20River%29">Pleasant River</a>. First known as township T5 R8 NWP, the community was organized in 1819 as Brownville Plantation. It was named for Francis Brown (nephew of Moses Brown), who was a mill owner and trader from <a href="Newbury%2C%20Massachusetts">Newbury</a>, Massachusetts. In 1824, the town was incorporated as Brownville.
Early settlers were given to clear and cultivate. Farms produced <a href="hay">hay</a>, <a href="oats">oats</a>, <a href="potatoes">potatoes</a>, <a href="wheat">wheat</a> and garden <a href="vegetables">vegetables</a>. <a href="Water%20power">Water power</a> from the Pleasant River attracted industry, including <a href="sawmill">sawmill</a>s, <a href="Clapboard%20%28architecture%29">clapboard</a> mills, <a href="gristmill">gristmill</a>s, a shovel handle factory and a <a href="carriage">carriage</a> factory. <a href="Quarry">Quarries</a> were established to extract the region's abundant <a href="slate">slate</a>, the quality of which won first prize at the 1876 <a href="Centennial%20Exposition">Centennial Exposition</a>. In 1843, the Bangor & Piscataquis Slate Company opened with 60 employees. It sent out 8,000-12,000 squares of roofing slate annually. The Merrill Quarry opened in 1846 with about 80 employees, producing 30,000 squares of roofing slate annually. The Highland Quarry opened with <a href="Welsh%20people">Welsh</a> employees, recruited because they were accustomed to working in slate. The last quarry closed in 1917.
<a href="Iron%20ore">Iron ore</a> was discovered at the foot of Ore Mountain. The <a href="Katahdin%20Iron%20Works">Katahdin Iron Works</a> was established in 1843, when roads were cut out and a <a href="blast%20furnace">blast furnace</a> erected. A hotel and several houses were built for workers. <a href="Charcoal">Charcoal</a> was made in 14 <a href="kiln">kiln</a>s, consuming 10,000 <a href="cord%20%28unit%20of%20volume%29">cords</a> of wood per year. The company and land were sold in 1845, and the new owners operated it until 1856, the year it produced 2350 tons of iron. However, shipping it to <a href="Bangor%2C%20Maine">Bangor</a> was expensive. The <a href="Bangor%20and%20Katahdin%20Iron%20Works%20Railway">Bangor and Katahdin Iron Works Railway</a> (B&KIW) was constructed to Brownville in 1881, then connected north to the Katahdin Iron Works in 1883.
In 1889 the <a href="International%20Railway%20of%20Maine">International Railway of Maine</a> was constructed by its owner <a href="Canadian%20Pacific%20Railway">Canadian Pacific Railway</a> (CPR), extending the CPR's transcontinental mainline east from <a href="Montreal">Montreal</a>, <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a> to <a href="Saint%20John%2C%20New%20Brunswick">Saint John, New Brunswick</a>. The CPR line passed 3 miles north of Brownville, where it crossed the B&KIW at a location that was named <a href="Brownville%20Junction%2C%20Maine">Brownville Junction</a>. In 1891 the B&KIW merged into the <a href="Bangor%20and%20Aroostook%20Railroad">Bangor and Aroostook Railroad</a> (BAR) after the Katahdin Iron Works closed the previous year. The BAR line as well as the CPR line west of Brownville became part of the <a href="Montreal%2C%20Maine%20and%20Atlantic%20Railway">Montreal, Maine and Atlantic Railway</a> and are now part of the <a href="Central%20Maine%20and%20Qu%C3%A9bec%20Railway">Central Maine and Québec Railway</a>. In 2019, the <a href="Canadian%20Pacific%20Railway">Canadian Pacific Railway</a> purchased the <a href="Central%20Maine%20and%20Qu%C3%A9bec%20Railway">Central Maine and Québec Railway</a>, once again, giving the railway access to the <a href="Port%20of%20Saint%20John">Port of Saint John</a> running trains from <a href="Brownville%20Junction%2C%20Maine">Brownville Junction</a> to <a href="New%20Brunswick">New Brunswick</a> via <a href="New%20Brunswick%20Southern%20Railway">New Brunswick Southern Railway</a>.
Local historian Bill Sawtell has documented many facets of the history of Brownville as well as the surrounding area. He has published numerous books with subjects such as Katahdin Iron Works, the Highland Quarry, the Bangor and Aroostook Railroad, and <a href="Penquis%20Valley%20High%20School">Penquis Valley High School</a> basketball.
Geography.
According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, the town has a total area of , of which, is land and is water. Situated between Sebec and Schoodic lakes, Brownville is drained by the <a href="Pleasant%20River%20%28Piscataquis%20River%29">Pleasant River</a>.
Climate.
This <a href="climate">climatic</a> region is typified by large seasonal temperature differences, with warm to hot (and often humid) summers and cold (sometimes severely cold) winters. According to the <a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20Climate%20Classification">Köppen Climate Classification</a> system, Brownville has a <a href="humid%20continental%20climate">humid continental climate</a>, abbreviated "Dfb" on climate maps.
Demographics.
2010 census.
As of the <a href="census">census</a> of 2010, there were 1,250 people, 527 households, and 347 families living in the town. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was . There were 738 housing units at an average density of . The racial makeup of the town was 97.3% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 0.6% <a href="African%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">African American</a>, 0.2% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 0.5% from <a href="Race%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 1.4% from two or more races. <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> people of any race were 1.3% of the population.
There were 527 households, of which 29.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 48.0% were <a href="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 9.9% had a female householder with no husband present, 8.0% had a male householder with no wife present, and 34.2% were non-families. 27.9% of all households were made up of individuals, and 12.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.37 and the average family size was 2.82.
The median age in the town was 44.5 years. 22.7% of residents were under the age of 18; 6.5% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 21.4% were from 25 to 44; 32.1% were from 45 to 64; and 17.4% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the town was 52.8% male and 47.2% female.
2000 census.
As of the <a href="census">census</a> of 2000, there were 1,259 people, 555 households, and 360 families living in the town. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was 28.4 people per square mile (11.0/km2). There were 726 housing units at an average density of 16.4 per square mile (6.3/km2). The racial makeup of the town was 98.09% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 1.03% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 0.08% <a href="Asian%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 0.24% from <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 0.56% from two or more races. <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> people of any race were 0.87% of the population.
There were 555 households, out of which 25.9% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 54.4% were <a href="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 7.0% had a female householder with no husband present, and 35.0% were non-families. 31.0% of all households were made up of individuals, and 19.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.26 and the average family size was 2.80.
In the town, the population was spread out, with 21.8% under the age of 18, 6.1% from 18 to 24, 25.6% from 25 to 44, 26.1% from 45 to 64, and 20.4% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 43 years. For every 100 females, there were 94.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 92.4 males.
The median income for a household in the town was $28,167, and the median income for a family was $35,446. Males had a median income of $31,141 versus $18,382 for females. The <a href="per%20capita%20income">per capita income</a> for the town was $14,774. About 12.1% of families and 13.6% of the population were below the <a href="poverty%20line">poverty line</a>, including 12.5% of those under age 18 and 12.3% of those age 65 or over.
